OCTOBER24,2016 NMX-J-266-ANCE-2016♦CSAC22.2NO.5-16♦UL489 311
SUPPLEMENT SH – MOLDED-CASE CIRCUIT BREAKERS WITH ADDITIONAL MOTOR
OVERLOAD PROTECTION
INTRODUCTION
SH1 Scope
SH1.1 These requirements cover motor protection molded-case circuit breakers intended for use as
service entrance, feeder, and branch circuit protection and, in addition, that provide motor disconnect,
short-circuit and ground-fault, and branch-circuit overload protection in accordance with the National
Installation Codes in Annex B, Ref. No. 1. A circuit breaker used as motor and branch-circuit overload
protectionshallcomplywiththeapplicablerequirementsoftheprecedingsectionsofthisstandard,except
as modified or added to by the requirements in this supplement.
SH1.2 Thesecircuitbreakersareintendedtobeusedincombinationwithacontactorinaccordancewith
Annex B, Ref. Nos. 25 and 26, as a component of a Combination Motor Controller.
SH1.3 These requirements are not intended to replace requirements in the National Installation Codes
which allow a standard circuit breaker to function also as a separate overload device in a motor branch
circuitwherethecircuitbreakerprovidesbothmotorbranch-circuitshort-circuitandground-faultprotection
and motor overload protection.
CONSTRUCTION
SH2 General
SH2.1 Circuit breakers intended for use as motor protection shall be permitted to have an adjustable
current setting that corresponds to motor full-load current. The motor full-load current setting shall be
inferred from the circuit breaker’s settings, markings, or instruction literature.
SH2.2 Thesecircuitbreakersshallnotbeabletobeadjustedsuchthattheydonotfunctionasastandard
breaker.

312 NMX-J-266-ANCE-2016♦CSAC22.2NO.5-16♦UL489 OCTOBER24,2016
PERFORMANCE
SH3 Motor Overload Calibration Test
SH3.1 When tested at an ambient temperature of 40°C (104°F), a circuit breaker shall trip:
a) Ultimately when carrying 100 percent of the rated tripping current corresponding to the motor
full-load current value or setting, if adjustable;
b) Within 8 minutes when carrying 200 percent of the rated tripping current corresponding to
the motor full-load current value or setting, if adjustable; and
c) Within:
1) 20 seconds when carrying 600 percent of the rated tripping current corresponding to
the motor full-load current value or setting, if adjustable; or
2) The time specified in Table SH4.1 if marked in accordance with SH4.3.
SH3.2 NotwithstandingSH3.1,circuitbreakersemployingsolidstatetrippingarenotrequiredtobetested
in a 40°C (104°F) ambient.
SH3.3 The calibration test sequence with respect to SH3.1 shall be the test in SH3.1 (c), followed by the
testinSH3.1(b),followedbythetestinSH3.1(a),allconductedonthesamecircuitbreakerandtripunits.
The circuit breaker and trip units shall be cooled to ambient temperature between tests.
SH3.4 A circuit breaker shall be mounted and connected as specified in the temperature test for a non
100 percent circuit breaker in 7.1.4.1.2.
SH3.5 If a circuit breaker is provided with an adjustable current setting that corresponds to a range of
motor full-load current ratings, the circuit breaker shall comply with the requirements in SH3.1 at the
minimum and maxumum current setting, to cover the entire range of adjustment.
SH3.6 If the circuit breaker overload function is ambient compensated, it shall be subjected to the tests
in SH3.1 in an ambient temperature of 40°C (104°F), and also in an ambient temperature of 25°C (77°F)
and an ambient temperature of 50°C (122°F).
SH3.7 Notwithstanding SH3.6, this requirement does not apply to circuit breakers employing solid state
tripping.
SH3.8 A circuit breaker intended for polyphase use shall be calibrated with only two poles in the circuit
during 600 and 200 percent calibration tests to cover single-phasing and with three poles in the circuit
during 100 percent tests.
SH3.9 Notwithstanding SH3.8, an electronic circuit breaker that offers loss of phase protection is not
required to be calibrated at 600 percent and 200 percent to cover single-phasing. For this type of circuit
breaker, the tests at 600 percent and 200 percent shall be conducted with three poles in the circuit.

OCTOBER24,2016 NMX-J-266-ANCE-2016♦CSAC22.2NO.5-16♦UL489 313
SH3.10 Acircuitbreakeremployingonepoleforsingle-phaseuseshallbecalibratedwithonepoleinthe
circuit during all tests. A circuit breaker employing two poles for single-phase use shall be calibrated with
two poles in the circuit during all tests.
MARKINGS
SH4 General
SH4.1 In addition to the requirements in SH4.2 – SH4.6, a circuit breaker shall be provided with all the
applicable required markings specified in the marking sections of this Standard.
SH4.2 AcircuitbreakerthatcomplieswiththerequirementsinSH1–SH3,inadditiontotherequirements
in this Standard, is permitted to be marked ″Motor Protection Circuit Breaker″. If provided, this marking
shall be on the circuit breaker.
SH4.3 With reference to SH3.1 (c), a circuit breaker shall be marked to indicate the tripping class
designation in accordance with Table SH4.1. The tripping class designation identifies the tripping time of
the circuit breaker when carrying 600 percent of the rated tripping current corresponding to the motor
full-load current value or setting. This marking shall be provided on the circuit breaker.
Table SH4.1
Marking designation for tripping time at 600 percent of the rated tripping current
Class20b 20
aClassdesignationsinexcessof30secondsmaybeused,withthetrippingtimeinsecondsequaltothenumericalclass
marking.
bClass20neednotbemarked.
SH4.4 The tripping current shall be marked on the circuit breaker and is permitted to be specified as a
percentage.
SH4.5 The outside ambient temperature of 40°C (104°F) on which the rating of the motor overload
protection is based shall be marked. This marking shall be provided on the circuit breaker.
SH4.6 Notwithstanding SH4.5, this requirement does not apply to circuit breakers employing solid state
tripping.
